en.safe_value: Introduction to two-factor authentication
en.value: Introduction to two-factor authentication

en.safe_value:
Two-factor authentication (2fa) helps protect your account by requiring you to enter a single use code, in addition to your password, when you log in. With 2fa enabled, someone who gains access to your password will be unable to login unless he somehow obtains the code as well. Typically, this code will either be generated by a separate application on a mobile device or sent to you by SMS text message when you attempt to sign in. It will be different each time, and you will not be able to access your account without it. But neither will anyone else. Some services also allow you to print out a series of codes so that you can log in when you do not have access to your phone or computer.

One day, the election monitoring website of an Uzbeck activist sudenly began displaying pornographic images. 
It turned out that hackers had been able to redirect the Web address of the site to another server. They did 
this by breaking into the Gmail account used to register that Web address and changing the domain name 
service (DNS) account records. They also registered a different email address, which prevented the activist 
from proving that she was the real owner of the account. As a result, there was nothing she could do to regain 
control of her own Web address. She had a strong passphrase on her Gmail account, and the compromise 
was probably the result of malware installed on her computer. 2fa would have prevented this attack. Even with 
full control of the activist's computer, the attackers would not have been able to sign in to her account 
without access to the device — be it a phone, a second computer or a printout — containing her 2fa code.

— See another story about how 2fa could have prevented a journalist's account from being hacked

You can only use 2fa with services that support the feature. Below, we describe how to enable and use 2fa for a few popular services that support it, including Google (Gmail, Google Drive, Google+, Youtube and others), Twitter and Facebook. You can read elsewhere about how to enable 2fa for other popular services, including

  • Wordpress
  • Yahoo! Mail
  • Skype (when used with Microsoft account)
  • Dropbox
  • Evernote.
  • Hushmail

You can also refer to www.twofactorauth.org, which provides a comprehensive list of services that support 2fa.

The device you use to generate, receive or store your 2fa codes should be different from the device you use to sign in to your account. It is common, for example, to use a computer to log in and a phone to obtain the 2fa codes that allow you to do so. Even if you are not comfortable giving your mobile phone number to your service provider — or if receiving an SMS text message every time you log in would be unsafe or impractical — you can still use a smartphone as your 2fa device. Once synchronised with your service provider, applications like Google Authenticator and FreeOTP display a new 2fa code, every few seconds, that will allow you to sign in. (Despite its name, Google Authenticator works with any services that supports this form of 2fa.) Once configured, these tools generate the necessary codes without sending data or communicating with your service provider in any way.

Below, we describe how to install, configure and use Google Authenticator. FreeOTP works in a very similar way. And, if your service provider supports other ways to generate, receive or store 2fa codes, you should adopt whichever method is most appropriate for your circumstances.
en.value:
Two-factor authentication (2fa) helps protect your account by requiring you to enter a single use code, in addition to your password, when you log in. With 2fa enabled, someone who gains access to your password will be unable to login unless he somehow obtains the code as well. Typically, this code will either be generated by a separate application on a mobile device or sent to you by SMS text message when you attempt to sign in. It will be different each time, and you will not be able to access your account without it. But neither will anyone else. Some services also allow you to print out a series of codes so that you can log in when you do not have access to your phone or computer.

    One day, the election monitoring website of an Uzbeck activist sudenly began displaying pornographic images. 
    It turned out that hackers had been able to redirect the Web address of the site to another server. They did 
    this by breaking into the Gmail account used to register that Web address and changing the domain name 
    service (DNS) account records. They also registered a different email address, which prevented the activist 
    from proving that she was the real owner of the account. As a result, there was nothing she could do to regain 
    control of her own Web address. She had a strong passphrase on her Gmail account, and the compromise 
    was probably the result of malware installed on her computer. 2fa would have prevented this attack. Even with 
    full control of the activist's computer, the attackers would not have been able to sign in to her account 
    without access to the device — be it a phone, a second computer or a printout — containing her 2fa code.

— *See another story about [how 2fa could have prevented a journalist's account from being hacked](http://www.wired.com/2012/08/apple-amazon-mat-honan-hacking/)*

You can only use 2fa with services that support the feature. Below, we describe how to enable and use 2fa for a few popular services that support it, including Google (Gmail, Google Drive, Google+, Youtube and others), Twitter and Facebook. You can read elsewhere about how to enable 2fa for other popular services, including 

- [Wordpress](https://en.support.wordpress.com/security/two-step-authentication/)
- [Yahoo! Mail](https://help.yahoo.com/kb/SLN5013.html)
- [Skype](http://windows.microsoft.com/en-au/windows/two-step-verification-faq) (when used with Microsoft account)
- [Dropbox](https://www.dropbox.com/en/help/363)
- [Evernote](https://blog.evernote.com/blog/2013/10/04/two-step-verification-available-to-all-users/). 
- [Hushmail](https://help.hushmail.com/entries/63282756-Two-step-verification)

You can also refer to [www.twofactorauth.org](https://twofactorauth.org/), which provides a comprehensive list of services that support 2fa.

The device you use to generate, receive or store your 2fa codes should be different from the device you use to sign in to your account. It is common, for example, to use a computer to log in and a phone to obtain the 2fa codes that allow you to do so. Even if you are not comfortable giving your mobile phone number to your service provider — or if receiving an SMS text message every time you log in would be unsafe or impractical — you can still use a smartphone as your 2fa device. Once synchronised with your service provider, applications like [Google Authenticator](https://support.google.com/accounts/answer/1066447?hl=en) and [FreeOTP](https://fedorahosted.org/freeotp) display a new 2fa code, every few seconds, that will allow you to sign in. (Despite its name, Google Authenticator works with any services that supports this form of 2fa.) Once configured, these tools generate the necessary codes without sending data or communicating with your service provider in any way.

Below, we describe how to install, configure and use Google Authenticator. FreeOTP works in a very similar way. And, if your service provider supports other ways to generate, receive or store 2fa codes, you should adopt whichever method is most appropriate for your circumstances.

und.safe_value: One day, the election monitoring website of an Uzbeck activist sudenly began displaying pornographic images. It turned out that hackers had been able to redirect the Web address of the site to another server. They did this by breaking into the Gmail account used to register that Web address and changing the domain name service (DNS) account records. They also registered a different email address, which prevented the activist from proving that she was the real owner of the account. As a result, there was nothing she could do to regain control of her own Web address. She had a strong passphrase on her Gmail account, and the compromise was probably the result of malware installed on her computer. 2fa would have prevented this attack. Even with full control of the activist's computer, the attackers would not have been able to sign in to her account without access to the device — be it a phone, a second computer or a printout — containing her 2fa code.
